title: freedom
comment: The state of liberty that results from not being oppressed or in bondage. Scripture stresses that human beings lack freedom on account of sin, but that faith in Jesus Christ brings freedom from the power of sin and the law.

children.title: freedom, acts of in OT
children.comment: The OT provides many examples of God delivering his people from bondage, of which the greatest is the exodus. These acts of deliverance foreshadow and prepare the way for the redeeming work of God through Jesus Christ, revealed in the NT.

children.title: God's people regain their freedom
The exodus from Egypt as an act of deliverance

seealsos.comment: The people of Israel were frequently reminded that God had delivered them from Egypt

children.title: The return from exile in Babylon as an act of deliverance
Freedom granted to individuals to reflect God's past deliverance

secondaryrefs.comment: the sabbath year: all servants to be freed after six years

children.title: God's purposes in bringing about his people's freedom
God sets his people free to be his own
God sets his people free to serve him
God sets his people free to praise him
God sets his people free to be holy
God sets his people free to receive his promised gifts

secondaryrefs.comment: The inheritance is the promised land of Canaan, which foreshadows the gospel inheritance of eternal life in the kingdom of God

children.title: Freedom is conditional upon obedience
Israel is commanded to remember the exodus as a matter of obedience
Israel's freedom depends upon continuing obedience to the LORD
Examples of Israel forfeiting freedom through sin
freedom, through Jesus Christ
children.comment: Jesus Christ, the promised deliverer, sets his people free from the present effects of sin and from the power of sin and will finally deliver them completely from its presence.

children.title: The OT points ahead to a new and greater freedom and to a new deliverer
The OT predicts Jesus Christ as the deliverer
The redemption of the exodus foreshadows the redemption achieved by Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ fulfils the OT predictions of him as deliverer
The freedom that comes through Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ sets his people free from the penalty of sin
Jesus Christ sets his people free from the spiritual death that accompanies sin
Jesus Christ sets his people free from the fear of death
Jesus Christ will finally set his people free from death itself
Jesus Christ sets his people free from the power of sin
Jesus Christ sets his people free from the pollution of sin
Jesus Christ sets his people free from the power of Satan

seealsos.comment: The strong man is, by implication, Jesus Christ

children.title: Jesus Christ will set his people free from the presence of sin
Freedom as the result of being rescued from trials by Jesus Christ
freedom, and the law
children.comment: Jesus Christ sets his people free from the condemnation and oppression of the law. Through the Holy Spirit, believers are able to fulfil the law obediently according to God's intentions.

children.title: Jesus Christ sets believers free from the law
Jesus Christ's life of perfect obedience to the law was the fulfilment of it
Jesus Christ's death fulfils the demands of the law
On account of Jesus Christ's death, believers can be righteous independently of the law
Believers are set free from the law's condemnation

seealsos.comment: The lives of Abraham, Sarah, Hagar, Ishmael and Isaac are interpreted figuratively, to illustrate the believer's freedom from the law's condemnation

children.title: The freedom of believers rests on the power of the Holy Spirit
The believer's freedom to obey the law voluntarily
freedom, abuse of Christian
children.comment: Although Christians have been set free from condemnation by grace, they remain under an obligation to be obedient to God. Abuses of Christian freedom result from a failure to take responsibilities towards God seriously.

children.title: Christian freedom can be abused
Believers are freed from condemnation
Sin need not enslave believers
Believers must resist sin
The false idea that grace gives believers the freedom to sin
The dangers of abusing Christian freedom
Becoming a stumbling-block to others
Indulging oneself
Using freedom to cover up evil
Examples of abuse of Christian freedom
Falling back into deliberate sin
Disobedience towards God
Selfishness
Eating food sacrificed to idols
freedom, of the will
children.comment: The ability to make decisions without being coerced by external forces. Scripture stresses that people are confronted with free choices between good and evil and commands them to choose good. However, it also notes that limitations are placed upon human actions through the enslaving power of sin.

children.title: Freedom of the will
Freedom of the will to choose between good and evil
Freedom of the will to seek and find God
The effect of sin upon freedom of the will
Sin prevents human beings from breaking free from its bondage

seealsos.comment: Paul stresses that it is only through Jesus Christ that human beings can be freed from servitude to sin.

children.title: Sin hardens human hearts
God hardens human hearts
Human beings harden their own hearts
